title: Arthur Cocks (cricketer)
text:
Arthur Denis Bradford Cocks (29 July 1904 – 6 June 1944) was an English first-class cricketer and <a href="British%20Army">British Army</a> officer. Cooke served with the <a href="Royal%20Engineers">Royal Engineers</a> from 1925–1944, serving in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a>, in which he was the first British officer killed on <a href="Normandy%20landings">D-Day</a>. He also played <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for the <a href="British%20Army%20cricket%20team">British Army cricket team</a>.
Life and military career.
The son of <a href="George%20Cocks">George Arthur Cocks</a> and his wife, Annie Violet Cocks, he was born in <a href="British%20India">British India</a> at <a href="Dharamshala">Dharamshala</a>. Cocks was educated in England at <a href="Bedford%20School">Bedford School</a>, where he played cricket for the school team. He played <a href="Minor%20Counties%20of%20English%20and%20Welsh%20cricket">minor counties cricket</a> for <a href="Bedfordshire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Bedfordshire</a> in 1924, making a single appearance in the <a href="Minor%20Counties%20Championship">Minor Counties Championship</a>. After leaving Bedford, he decided on a career in the army and attended the <a href="Royal%20Military%20Academy%2C%20Woolwich">Royal Military Academy, Woolwich</a>. He graduated from Woolwich in January 1925, entering into the <a href="Royal%20Engineers">Royal Engineers</a> as a <a href="Second_lieutenant%23United_Kingdom_%26amp%3B_other_Commonwealth_countries">second lieutenant</a>. He was promoted to the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">lieutenant</a> in January 1927. In May of the same year he made his debut in <a href="first-class%20cricket">first-class cricket</a> for the <a href="British%20Army%20cricket%20team">British Army cricket team</a> against <a href="Oxford%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Oxford University</a> at <a href="University_Parks%23Cricket_ground">Oxford</a>, before making a second appearance in June against <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a> at <a href="Fenner%27s">Fenner's</a>. He scored 30 runs in his two first-class appearances, while with the ball he bowled a total of 51 wicketless <a href="over%20%28cricket%29">overs</a>. 
He married Majorie Du Caurroy Chads in 1932 and shortly after served in <a href="British%20rule%20in%20Burma">British Burma</a>, where he was stationed at <a href="Rangoon">Rangoon</a>. He returned to England in 1936, where he was promoted to the rank of <a href="Captain%20%28British%20Army%20and%20Royal%20Marines%29">captain</a> in January, before being seconded to the <a href="War%20Office">War Office</a> as a staff captain in December 1937. He relinquished his appointment at the war office in January 1939. He served in the <a href="Second%20World%20War">Second World War</a> with the Royal Engineers, during which he was promoted to the rank of <a href="Major%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">major</a> in January 1942, with a further promotion to the rank of <a href="Lieutenant%20colonel%20%28United%20Kingdom%29">lieutenant colonel</a>. On <a href="Normandy%20landings">D-Day</a> he landed at <a href="Sword%20Beach">Sword Beach</a> with the 5th Assault Regiment, known as the 'Hobart's Funnies', in the course of which he was killed in action. He was the first British officer to be killed on D-Day. His body was returned to England and buried at St. Peter's Church, <a href="Frimley">Frimley</a>.
